INTRODUCTION

In response to the city of Baltimore, the Occupational Safety and

Health Administration (OSHA), and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), this Process Safety

Management/Risk Management Program (PSM/RMP) document has been developed for the Merchants

Terminal facility located at: 4851 Holabird Ave., Baltimore, MD 21224. This document has been

prepared to satisfy multiple regulations and is governed by the following agencies:

1. OSHA's Code of Regulations, OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly

Hazardous Chemicals (PSM)

2. Federal EPA's, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention

Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r), Program 3

Requirements (RMP)

The purpose of this document is to:

1. Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring

proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.

2. Assist Merchants Terminal and local government agencies in their communication and

coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.

This document addresses Merchants Terminal administrative and operational programs to prevent

accidents related to regulated substances and to reduce potential risks. The regulated substance of

concern and focus of this document is anhydrous ammonia. Ammonia is used to provide refrigeration

for warehouse cold storage and dock operations.

This Executive Summary contains tables outlining the PSM/RMP sections. It includes the purpose,

frequency of use, responsibilities and requirements, and forms for each section of the PSM/RMP

program.



FACILITY DESCRIPTION

Merchants Terminal operates a refrigeration system utilizing anhydrous ammonia as the primary

refrigerant. The refrigeration system is located in the main building.

Mechanical refrigeration is a thermodynamic process where the refrigerant, ammonia, is used as

a heat

exchanging fluid to maintain a desired temperature in an enclosed environment. The refrigeration cycle

consists of evaporation, compression, condensation, and expansion. Evaporation and condensation are

designed to alter the quantity of energy associated with refrigerant. Compression and expansion are

designed to change the availability of the associated energy. The refrigeration cycle is a closed-loop

process. The ammonia refrigeration cycle utilizes fluid temperature, pressure, and latent heat of

vaporization for cooling. The refrigeration system utilizes these phenomenons to remove heat from a

desired area, and then to discard that heat, through condensation, to an area where it is of no

consequence.

The Merchants Terminal facility utilizes ammonia refrigeration to cool various storage areas. The

refrigeration system contains the following equipment: nine screw compressors, three evaporative

condensers, one -43?F recirculator with pumps, one -25?F recirculator with pumps, one high pressure

receiver, one thermosyphon receiver, six blast cells evaporators, four minus -20?F penthouse evaporators,

eighteen -10?F penthouse evaporators, two cooler penthouse evaporators, and eight dock evaporators.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION

Every section of the RMP/PSM program must allow for employee participation in its development and

implementation. The plan allowing for this participation must be documented. Employees and their

representatives must have access to all information that is developed, for the Process Safety

Management program without regard to possible trade secret status of such information.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

All employees especially those new to the facility or transferred from another department



Director of Engineering or Designee

Notifying all employees of the use of ammonia at the facility. 

Provide information and hazards related to ammonia to employees.

Annually



Director of Engineering or Designee

Information on the most likely accident scenarios and consequences of ammonia releases.

Related Form: PSM/RMP COMMITTEE REVIEW FORM

This form can be found in the Employee Participation Section of this manual.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION

Complete and accurate written information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and

process equipment is essential to an effective RMP/PSM program and to other aspects such as the

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA). The information to be compiled about the chemicals needs to be

comprehensive enough for an accurate assessment of the fire and explosion characteristics, reactivity

hazards, the health and safety hazards to workers, and the corrosion effects on process equipment as well

as monitoring and safety related equipment. MSDS information can provide a portion of the required

data but other information will be required.

Process technology information is also required. This includes information on the amount of hazardous

material stored and used at the facility as well as operating limits for the process. Diagrams of the

system and information on all of the equipment utilized in the system are required. Piping and

instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) are required in the Process Hazard Analysis and are included in the

Process Safety Information.



Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Update if a change is made and train operators at least every three years

Director of Engineering or Designee

Make available to all employees who work on or near the equipment of the ammonia process.

Related Form: NOT APPLICABLE



PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS

The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is the basis for many of the decisions and procedures associated

with an effective PSM/RMP program. It is a systematic effort to determine the potential hazards

associated with the process and to evaluate mitigation alternatives including equipment modifications,

procedural modifications, training, and administrative controls. An

effective PHA considers and

analyzes the potential consequences associated with a release of the hazardous materials including fires,

explosions, and exposure of people to toxic materials. It focuses on equipment, instrumentation,

utilities, human actions, and external events.

To ensure that both operator safety as well as off-site safety is addressed, the A?What-IfA? Checklist

analysis was conducted during the PHA session. Human factors such as lighting, accessibility, and

overall working conditions were incorporated in the analysis.



Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Review and update hazard assessments or process hazard analysis at least every five years or

as the result of a change.

Director of Engineering or Designee

Make available to all employees who work on or near the equipment of the ammonia process.

If no changes have occurred since initial PHA, include a statement to this fact in the document.

Related Form: NOT APPLICABLE



OPERATING PROCEDURES

Operating procedures describe all employee tasks, data to be recorded, operating conditions to be

maintained, and safety and health precautions to be utilized in operation of the process containing

regulated substances. The procedures need to be technically accurate and will result in safe operation of

the facility. In addition, they need to be understandable to the employees and/or contractors. The

procedures must be updated as changes are made to the facility or to the operating limits of the system.

The regulations require that the employer annually certify that the operating procedures are current and

accurate.

All phases of system operation must be covered by written procedures. Specifically, procedures must be

available for:

1. Initial startup

2. Normal operation

3. Temporary operations as the need arises

4. Emergency shutdown

5. Normal shutdown

6. Emergency Operations

7. Startup following a turnaround, or after an emergency shutdown

The procedures contain proce

ss operation limits and provide information of the consequences of

deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct any deviations. Safety and health measures

are included in the procedures to warn employees of potential risks and protective action that should be

taken.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

As often as necessary. Director of Engineering or Designee

Operating Procedures reviewed to reflect any changes in the facility

Annually Director of Engineering or Designee

Operating Procedure Review where each procedure is reviewed and

decided to be either:

1. Current

2. Still used, but needs updating

3. No longer needed.

Results are documented on the SOP REVIEW SUMMARY & CERTIFICATION form.

Related form: SOP REVIEW SUMMARY & CERTIFICATION

This form can be found in the SOP section of this manual.



EMPLOYEE TRAINING

All employees, including maintenance and contractor employees involved with regulated substances (i.e.

ammonia) need to fully understand the health and safety hazards associated with the chemical with

which they are working. This will allow them to better protect themselves, fellow employees, and the

neighboring communities. In addition to the normal awareness training, which informs personnel of the

hazards of the chemical and the safety precautions to use, training in operating procedures and practices,

emergency response, and other required management controls are required.

Employees must identify the personnel who require training, develop a training protocol with procedures

and objectives, and maintain a record of personnel training. Regular evaluation of the training program

must be accomplished to ensure that it is appropriate information to the employees in a useful and

understandable way.

If outside employees (maintenance or contract) are performing work which might impact the ammonia

refrigeration system, the Director of Engineering or his Designee has an obligation to assure that they

hav

e been properly trained by their employer and have been informed of any hazardous conditions and

the proper procedures to be utilized at the facility.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Initial training for new employees.

Director of Engineering or Designee

1. Generalized training during orientation period and specific training

once assigned to a department.

2. Specialized training includes.

            a. Labeling of all ammonia materials uses and references to the Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS).

            b. Providing ammonia information consisting of the Process Safety Information, Process Hazards Analysis and the Employee Training sections of this manual.

3. Employees sign a certification page that lists those requirements covered under the Employee Training section of this manual.

Refresher training/ Annually for all employees

Director of Engineering or Designee

1. Periodic training on unchanged procedures and policies:

     a. Competencies in handling regulated substance

     b. Items covered in classroom & on-the-job training

     c. Review of accidents and near misses associated with the use of ammonia

2. Training on the information, procedures and/or policies that have changed, including new process or a process equipment.

3. Hazard Communication Training, providing routine and non-routine training to department and workstation level employees.

Related Forms and Documents: Merchants Terminal TRAINING CERTIFICATION FORM (INITIAL TRAINING AND EMPLOYEE VERIFICATION), Industry A?Ammonia Refrigeration Training GuidelineA?

These forms and documents can be found in the Employee Training Section of this PSM/RMP.



CONTRACTOR SAFETY

Any use of outside contractors who work in and around the ammonia refrigeration system requires that

theses contractors have accomplished the training, utilize proficient personnel, and have been informed

of the necessary health and safety aspects of working in the area. The goal is to assure th

at contractor

employees perform work in a safe manner and do not endanger themselves, other employees, or the

facility. A plan for screening potential contractors to ensure satisfactory performance is required.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

In the event of hiring an outside contractor.

Director of Engineering or Designee

Evaluation of contractor's safety program, safety performance and programs prior to allowing them work at the facility

Inform contractor of potential fire and hazards related to the work and requiring contractor's signature on selected

forms before performing work. Depending on the event, these forms can include: OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR HAZARD COMMUNICATION FORM, 

OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR LOCKOUT- TAGOUT FORM, AMMONIA EMERGENCY PLAN INFORMATION RECEIPT, AND CONTRACTOR EMPLOYEE INJURY/ILLNESS LOG. 

An explanation of Merchants ammonia emergency plan and safe work practices before contractor's admittance into the facility.

Meetings following specific work (for a one-time effort) or annually (for ongoing programs such as ammonia system maintenance).

Director of Engineering or Designee

Evaluate performance of contract employees in meeting

their responsibilities, assuring that their safety-training

program is equivalent to the facilities program.

Deficiencies are immediately corrected.

On-going process Director of Engineering or Designee

A log of contract employees' injuries and illnesses related to contractor's work remain available to all employees and/or contractors.

On going process/as necessary Contractor Instruct contractor employees of potential fire and hazards.

Documents that employees receive training. Assures that employee follows Merchants Terminal Services safety rules. 

Advises Director of Engineering of any unique hazards presented.

Related Form: OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR HAZARD COMMUNICATION FORM, OUTSIDE CONTRACTOR LOCK OUT-TAG OUT FORM, CONTRACTOR SAFETY FORM, 

AMMONIA EMERGENCY PLAN INFORMATION RECEIPT, CONTRACTOR

EVALUATION, Merchants Terminal CONTRACTOR TRAINING CERTIFICATION

These forms can be found within the Contractor Safety Section of this manual.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW

For a new design or the addition of significant changes to the process, a Pre-Startup Safety Review

(PSSR) must be employed to determine that the changes are not themselves deficient or that the addition

of the new portions of the system will adversely affect the original system. Management procedures

must be developed to ensure that a satisfactory hazard analysis has been completed before the system is

started. The records from this Pre-Startup Safety Review must be kept on file.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

For all modifications that result in a change to the process safety information, the construction of a new facility, 

and/or for a prolonged shutdown of the process.

Director of Engineering or Designee

Process safety information is compiled a process hazard analysis performed; recommendations from the hazard analysis resolved; 

safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are written, implemented and adequate; construction and equipment is 

in accordance with design specification, and training for each employee involved in the process is completed

A PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW VERIFICATION form is signed when the above is documented.

Related Form: PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW VERIFICATION, PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW CHECKLIST

These forms can be found within the Pre-Startup Safety Review Section of this manual.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY

A formal maintenance program will be in place for all systems using regulated substances (i.e.

ammonia). This program will consist of routine (scheduled) inspection, testing, overhaul, and

replacement as needed. Equipment must be categorized and ranked with respect to the maintenance

involved. This maintenance and inspection information will include all equipment such as storage tanks,

compressors, condensers, evapor

ators, process piping relief and vent systems, fire protection system

components, emergency shutdown systems, and alarms. Each component must be placed into a category

that indicates how maintenance and inspection will be performed on that class of components.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Daily Merchants Terminal Maintenance personnel

Follow and complete the Daily Log Sheet- Engine Room

Weekly Merchants Terminal Maintenance personnel

Follow and complete the Merchants Terminal Weekly Ammonia Inspection Checklist

Monthly Maintenance Contractor 

Follow and complete the Merchants Terminal Monthly Ammonia Inspection Checklist

Quarterly Maintenance Contractor 

Follow and complete the Merchants Terminal Quarterly Ammonia Inspection Checklist

Semi-Annually Maintenance Contractor 

Follow and complete the Merchants Terminal Semi-Annual Ammonia Inspection Checklist

Annually Maintenance Contractor 

Follow and complete the Merchants Terminal Annual Ammonia Inspection Checklist

Five Year 3rd Party Inspector 

Follow and complete the Merchants Terminal Five-Year Ammonia Inspection Checklist

As Necessary Director of Engineering or Designee

If potentially faulty or unsafe equipment is observed by any employee, it is to be documented using the FAULTY OR UNSAFE

EQUIPMENT REPORT form. Management will respond to the observation in a written and timely manner and see to the correction

before the next use.

Related forms: Roundsheets and Inspection Forms

These forms can be found within the Mechanical Integrity Section of this manual.



HOT WORK PERMIT

A management control program must be employed that recognizes extra care is required for non-routine

work practices. This program will advise the personnel that significant potential hazards exist and that

extra care should be taken in certain circumstances. This will ensure that employees, contractors, and

company property are protected against fire, explosion, and other dangers resulting from ho

t work.

Formal procedures should exist for these programs and paperwork associated with ongoing work should

be kept for documentation.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Issued before beginning hot work. Requested by any facility employee or outside contractor.

Initiating a hot work permit the day that the hot work is to be performed.

Director of Engineering or a Chief Engineer

Issuing a hot work permit before hot work is started. List of precautions is reviewed with cutter/welder and the

firewatcher. Hot work permit is signed by appropriate parties. Sections 1 & 2 completed by Director of

Engineering (or designated representative).

Director of Engineering or a Chief Engineer

Performing hot work includes making the permit visible where hot work is being performed. Firewatcher looks for

fire hazards. 

Director of Engineering (or designated representative) inspects work area during operation.

Permit is kept on file for at least 30 days after all work is completed.

Director of Engineering or a Chief Engineer

Completion of hot work permit includes: inspecting area for 30 minutes after hot work performed: permit signed and

returned to Director of Engineering or a Chief Engineer who also inspects area and signs Section 3 of the hot work permit.

Copies sent to the Facilities Manager and the contractor, if appropriate.

Related Form: HOT WORK PERMIT

This form can be found within the Hot Work Permit Section of this manual.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE

Other than A?replacement in kind,A? any change to the system must be documented. In particular, the

change of any equipment, control system, or procedure must be evaluated to determine that it will not

have an adverse effect on the safety aspects of the system. In addition, procedures must be revised to

reflect the changes in the system.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Whenever there is a design change regarding the ammonia system.

Director of Engineering or Assistant Director o

f Engineering or Chief Engineer

A change includes: Modifications to the process Piping modifications Instrumental changes that result in the a

change to the system piping Procedural modifications Safety and health equipment Change to a "controlled" document

Building modifications including destruction or removal of equipment from service 

Initiator of a proposed change will prepare the Management of Change Record form and submit it to the responsible

party. A control number to this form is entered into the facility's

Management of Change Record Log form. If the work is a "replacement in kind" the record is signed off and filed, 

otherwise, the responsible party will coordinate the progress including the technical, safety, training, and

documentation requirements.

Emergency Basis- A management of change record must be initiated within 72 hours.

Maintenance Contractor Procedural change made on an emergency basis to improve safety of an operation.

Related Forms: Merchants Terminal MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE RECORD (MCR), MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE RECORD (MCR) LOG,

SAFETY REVIEW CHECKLIST

These forms can be found within the Management of Change Section of this manual.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

Incident investigation is the process of identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing

steps to prevent similar events from occurring. It is expected that employees will recognize and

investigate events that resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a hazardous chemical release.

Employees must develop in-house capability to investigate incidents that occur in their facilities. A team

should be assembled by Merchants Terminal and trained to collect and document information related to

any incident. Usually a multi-disciplinary team is better able to gather the facts and evaluate A?what

happened and why.A? All employees with information should be interviewed and other facts should be

gathered to develop a complete picture of the facts concerning the

incident. Recommendations are then

developed for changes in equipment, procedures, or safety systems to prevent recurrence of the event.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

A release or near release event. Director of Engineering or Assistant Director of Engineering

ASAP, but no later than 48 hours after an incident. A committee is assembled to determine the facts and the cause

of the incident and recommend corrective preventative actions. Information will be retained in the administrative

office and documentation is completed on the INCIDENT INVESTIGATION REPORT. Employees of Merchants Terminal will 

review the documentation once complete. The data will be retained for 5 years following implementation of the recommendations.

Related Forms: AMMONIA INCIDENT INVESTIGATION REPORT (INCIDENT SUMMARY: APPROVALS, FOLLOW-UP AND REVIEWS: REFRENCE NO. LOG)

This form can be found within the Incident Investigation Section of this manual.



EMERGENCY PLANNING AND RESPONSE

Emergency plans are required in case there is a release of ammonia (or other emergency such as fire or

earthquake). Employers must select a formal plan on how to handle an emergency situation and a plan

to educate employees as to what they should do. This plan must be detailed and include procedures for

notifying local authorities and following up with written accident reports, should the release meet or

exceed the reportable quantity (100 pounds of ammonia). Many local site factors will be included in the

ammonia emergency and fire prevention plan. Merchants Terminal has a stated policy of responding to

all leaks to determine the proper response. Merchants Terminal will respond to and mitigate all leaks

within the limits of training and with the proper use of PPE.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

In the case of a significant release of a hazardous material.

Director of Engineering or Assistant Director of Engineering

Determines extent of release or designates

someone to do so. Decides which personnel should be evacuated 

to the designated assembly areas. Immediately notifies all of the appropriate agencies. Is informed of 

any fire or ammonia emergencies and has the ultimate responsibility of facility personnel or contractors. 

Responsible for completing the HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENT REPORT.

Chief Engineer Performs the same responsibilities, as above if Incident Commander (IC) is not available.

Each Manager Performs roll call for the personnel in their department and reports to the IC. Brings first aid

kits to assembly area if applicable.

Ammonia Emergency and Fire Prevention Plan is reviewed:

1. Initially when the plan is developed

2. At the time of hire, for each new employee

3. When employee's responsibilities change

4. Whenever the plan changes

Refresher training is conducted at least annually

Chief Engineer or Assistant Chief Engineer Responsible for ensuring Emergency training for all employees, 

such as First Aid and Emergency Evacuation Training for operators and those associated with hazardous materials 

also receive Hazard Communication and HAZWOPER Training. Solicit input from all employees during a 2 week period 

following completion of each drill to correct any deficiencies found.

Related Forms: HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENT REPORT, CERIFICATION FOR AMMONIA EMERGENCY PLAN

These forms can be found within the Emergency Planning and Response Section of this manual.

1. First, call 911 on an internal landline phone for the Fire Department, Police

Department, Emergency Medical Services, and the Hazmat Team.

2. Call the Maryland Emergency Response Division 1-866-633-4686

3. Call Balti

more City LEPC at 410-396-6188

4. If additional help is required for an ammonia spill, the facility can call Chemtrec-

day at 1-800-222-1222.

COMPLIANCE SAFETY AUDITS

An effective audit program is required to determine that facility personnel and contractors are following

the procedures and intents of the overall PSM requirements. Periodic reviews of all areas of the

management programs are required to verify compliance. OSHA has published compliance guidelines

for their compliance personnel. These guidelines make a good basis for developing an internal audit

program. Corrective actions related to the audit will need to be documented and kept on record to show

how the audit is improving the overall performance of the risk management programs in place at the

facility.

Frequency of Use Responsible Party Requirements

Every 3 years. Director of Engineering or Assistant Director of Engineering

Includes verification that procedures developed to comply with the risk management regulations are adequate and are

being followed. The Compliance Audit form is used for this procedure. A written report of the findings of the audit is

developed and an appropriate response to each of the findings. Documentation showing that deficiencies have been corrected.

As necessary Merchants Terminal 

The two most recent audit reports shall be retained by the employer and made available to employees.

Related Forms: COMPLIANCE AUDIT FORMS

These forms can be found within the compliance Audit Section of this manual.
